questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.explanation: Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.question:
Question 2: During the autopsy of a 78-year-old man who had progressive memory loss for 2 years, the 
following histologic finding was noted in the brain tissue. Which of the following mechanisms 
is most likely responsible for this condition?

options.b: Conformational change in the prion protein

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the images showing amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are 
diagnostic of Alzheimer's disease (AD), complicated by cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). The 
formation and aggregation of A peptides are responsible for AD. 1310 
Sold by @itachibot Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is neurotrophic and neuroprotective. It is present in astrocytes 
and neuroglia. This protein is cleaved at 3 sites by secretase enzymes (,  , and ), and the 
products are known as A peptides. In Alzheimer's disease, A peptides get aggregated in the form of amyloid plaques, which stain 
positive for Congo red. These get deposited within the neural tissue (A 42) and the cerebral 
arterioles (A 40 protein, causing CAA), which causes neuronal dysfunction, and is the first sign of 
AD. Normally, tau proteins within the neurons stabilize microtubules, however, in AD, these get 
hyperphosphorylated and lose their function. Hyperphosphorylated tau proteins combine with 
cytoplasmic fibrils, to form neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and get abnormally accumulated 
around the neuronal nucleus.

questions.question: Question 5: In which of the following conditions can neurofibrillary tangles be found?
questions.explanation:
Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are found in: • Normal aging • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis • Alzheimer's disease NFTs are aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins (microtubule-associated proteins) found 
in numerous diseases known as tauopathies. NFTs can also be seen in relatively lower numbers in 
elderly people without dementia.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 43-year-old man who presented with tremors, bradykinesia, ■lack of coordination, and 
progressive declining cognitive functions was diagnosed with punch drunk syndrome. This 
condition is likely due to the deposition of which of the following in his brain?
questions.explanation:
Punch drunk syndrome is due to accumulation of tau proteins in the brain. This condition is also called dementia pugilistica or chronic traumatic encephalopathy. It is a 
dementing illness that develops following repeated head trauma in boxers and other athletes. 
Affected brains are typically atrophic, with enlarged ventricles. They show accumulation of tau-- 
containing□ neurofibrillary tangles in a characteristic pattern involving the superficial frontal and 
temporal lobe cortex.

questions.question:
Question 7: 1305 
Sold by @itachibot A 62-year-old man is brought with tremors of his hands at rest. His son says that he has 
difficulty initiating movements and seems to be moving very slowly. On examination, 
shuffling gait, pill-rolling tremors, and rigidity on passive arm movement are noted. Which of 
the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease. This condition is not associated 
with Pick cells and Pick bodies. They are seen in Pick’s disease or frontotemporal dementia. In Parkinson's disease, there is loss of the substantia nigra neurons projecting to the striatum. 
This leads to pallor of the substantia nigra as well as a decrease or absence of dopamine in the 
striatum. This leads to slowing of movements and tremors. Lewy Bodies are seen within the neurons of affected patients. They are filamentous projections of 
the protein ■synuclein or ubiquitin. They are present in surviving neurons and can be found in 
the cortex.

questions.question: Question 8: LRRK2 mutation is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
1312 
Sold by @itachibot Mutations in the gene encoding LRRK2 (leucine rich repeat kinase 2) are a common cause of 
autosomal dominant Parkinson's disease. They are also found in some sporadic cases of the 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 9: A wife brings her 52-year-old husband to the OPD with complaints of involuntary, sudden, 
jerky movements of his hands. She also tells that he has been occasionally forgetting the route 
to his office. His older brother also developed similar complaints last year. MRI revealed the 
following findings. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition? 1306 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It has an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance
options.b: The phenomenon of anticipation is seen
options.c: Severity is related to the length of the CAG repeats
options.d: There is degeneration of GABAergic neurons

questions.explanation:
The MRI shows bilateral atrophy of caudate nuclei with compensatory dilatation of lateral 
ventricles, also known as boxcar ventricles. Along with the clinical features, it is suggestive 
of Huntington's disease (HD). It has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. It is a degenerative disease of the caudate 
and putamen (striate neurons) caused by trinucleotide (CAG) repeats in the huntingtin gene 
on chromosome 4. The severity of the disease depends on the number of repeats. With more 
repeats, the disease becomes more severe. The disease also manifests at an earlier age, a 
phenomenon called anticipation. The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, 
cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle. The medium-sized GABAergic neurons 
are especially affected. It causes chorea and dementia. Motor problems like chorea typically precede dementia.

questions.question: Question 10: In patients with Huntington's disease, the mutated gene is located on which chromosome?
questions.explanation:
In Huntington's disease, the affected HTT gene is located on chromosome 4. The coding region has a trinucleotide repeat (CAG/ glutamine). The severity and age of onset of 
the disease depend on the number of repeats increases. This phenomenon is called anticipation.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with difficulty in climbing stairs and walking long 
distances. His parents say that he has received complaints at school due to progressively 
worsening handwriting. On examination, pes cavus is noted. Investigations revealed scoliosis 
and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this 
condition?

options.c: Expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Friedrich's ataxia. It is associated with mutations of 
genes on chromosome 9q13. It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the 
gene encoding frataxin. The clinical features are given by the mnemonic FRIEDRICHS: • F - Frequent falls (ataxia), foot deformity (pes cavus or overarched foot) • R - Recessive • I - Iron accumulation in mitochondria • E - Eye movements (nystagmus) • D - Dorsal column (loss of fine touch, vibration, position) • R - Reflexes (deep tendon) lost, with extensor plantar reflex • I - Incoordination 1313 
Sold by @itachibot • C - Cerebellar involvement • H - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) • S - Scoliosis (with kyphosis), staggering gait

questions.question:
Question 12: While studying a spinal cord section, a pathology resident noted that the nuclei of the 
Schwann cells of the dorsal root ganglia were enlarged nearly 5 times the normal size. This 
finding is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
In ataxia-telangiectasia, the nuclei of the Schwann cells of the dorsal root ganglia are enlarged to 
nearly 2-5 times the normal size. This finding is seen in the Schwann cells of dorsal root ganglia, 
peripheral nerves, endothelial cells, and pituicytes. These cells are called amphicytes. Ataxia-telangiectasia is due to mutations of the ATM gene, located on chromosome 
11q. It predominantly affects the cerebellum with the loss of Purkinje and granule cells. There is 
also degeneration of the dorsal columns, spinocerebellar tract, anterior horn cells, and peripheral 
neuropathy. Telangiectatic lesions are found in the CNS as well as in the conjunctiva and skin of the face, neck, 
and arms. The lymph nodes, thymus, and gonads are hypoplastic.

questions.question: Question 14: Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of Purkinje cells. It occurs in advanced cases of chronic alcoholism. There is a loss of Purkinje cells 
and proliferation of the adjacent astrocytes between the depleted granular cell layer and the 
molecular layer of the cerebellum.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with complaints of irritability, stiffness, and 
weakness of limbs. On examination, there was hypertonia of limbs. After a few months, the 
baby died due to the rapid progression of the disease. A brain autopsy was done and the 
following cells were seen. What are these cells? 1308 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
1314 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario showing motor symptoms and rapid progression to death, an autopsy of the 
brain showing globoid cells is highly suggestive of Krabbe's disease. The globoid cells are 
macrophages. Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe 
myelin destruction due to a deficiency of galactocerebroside  -galactosidase. The onset of symptoms is between 3 to 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as 
stiffness and weakness. Survival beyond the age of 2 years is uncommon. The brain shows loss of 
myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 35-year-old man presented with frequent falls and tingling in his extremities. On 
examination, an unsteady gait with a positive Romberg sign was noted. Additionally, there 
was loss of proprioception and vibration sense and deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. 
Blood investigations revealed the following. Deficiency of which of the following vitamins is 
the likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with involvement of the dorsal column and investigations 
showing macrocytic anemia is suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) of the spinal 
cord. It is due to a deficiency of vitamin B12 which is involved in myelin synthesis. The most severely affected regions are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic 
levels. The clinical features include: • Peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement • Paresthesias in the hands or feet • Weakness and unsteadiness of gait • Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the legs • Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucinations MRI spine shows diffuse myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Treatment involves a 
replacement regimen of vitamin B12 intramuscular daily injections of 1000 g for the first week 
followed by weekly 1000 g injections for 1 month. Monthly injections are given thereafter. 1315 
Sold by @itachibot While vitamin E deficiency can also cause SACD, it is rare and is associated with hemolytic 
anemia.

questions.question: Question 17: Korsakoff syndrome is caused by the deficiency of which vitamin?

options.a: BRAF mutation is seen in this tumor
options.d: It belongs to WHO grade II tumors

questions.explanation:
Korsakoff syndrome is caused by the deficiency of thiamine. This syndrome is characterized by pronounced anterograde and retrograde amnesia along with 
impairment in visuospatial, abstract, and other types of learning. It is usually completely or 
partially permanent in about half the patients. Wernicke's encephalopathy refers to the acute form of thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by 
nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait. It is 
a medical emergency and IV or IM thiamine should be initiated immediately. 1316 
Sold by @itachibot CNS Tumours
